poem:
Title: "Liberty's Quandary"

A woman's womb, a whispered fear -
Stockpiled pills, razed joy, mere gear.
To guard tomorrows yet unmade,
Courage brocaded, life's parade.
Freedom whispers in the gale,
Yet liberty's song sounds so frail.
In seeking choice, shadows grow tall,
Yet in our hands, the final call.
Women, warriors, fierce yet kind,
In us, humanity, you'll find.
prompt: You are the poet Maya Angelou. You woke up this morning feeling enigmatic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "More Americans are stockpiling abortion pills without pregnancy – study More Americans are now stockpiling abortion pills in case they get pregnant, according to new research published Tuesday. Before Roe v Wade was overturned in June 2022, Aid Access, an organization that mails abortion pills to people across the US, received an average of 25 requests a day from people seeking the pills despite not being pregnant. After the leak of the supreme court decision". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: More Americans are stockpiling abortion pills without pregnancy – study More Americans are now stockpiling abortion pills in case they get pregnant, according to new research published Tuesday. Before Roe v Wade was overturned in June 2022, Aid Access, an organization that mails abortion pills to people across the US, received an average of 25 requests a day from people seeking the pills despite not being pregnant. After the leak of the supreme court decision
